snippet: Lipka Tatars, despite 600-year-old roots in Poland, increasingly find themselves navigating between religion and nationality as the country argues over accepting migrants.
abstract: Poland's Tatars, largely overlooked minority Muslim group with 600-year-old roots in country, have found themselves target of threats and anger as Poland's right-wing nationalist Law and Justice party has come to power, in no small part due to migrant crisis in Europe; Tatars support government's hard-line stance on restricting flow of Muslim migrants, largely because they view influx as threat to their identity and stability.
lead_paragraph: Lipka Tatars, despite 600-year-old roots in Poland, increasingly find themselves navigating between religion and nationality as the country argues over accepting migrants.

headline.main: Poland’s Tatars Feel Uncertain as Anti-Muslim Sentiment Grows

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
